Parametric Bootstrapping for Indirect Effects

Ivan Jacob Agaloos Pesigan and Shu Fai Cheung

2020-06-26

Source: vignettes/AMOM.Rmd
AMOM.Rmd

Indirect Effect

\[\begin{equation} M = \delta_M + \alpha X + \varepsilon_M \end{equation}\]

\[\begin{equation} Y = \delta_Y + \tau^{\prime} X + \beta M + \varepsilon_Y \end{equation}\]

\[\begin{equation} \mathrm{Indirect \ Effect} = \alpha \beta \end{equation}\]

The Simple Mediation Model

Nonparametric Bootstrapping

  • Resample the original sample data with replacement \(B\) number of times
  • Fit the model on each of the bootstrap resample
  • Obtain quantiles from the sampling distribution of the statistic of interest

Parametric Bootstrapping

  • Generate data using parameter estimates from the original sample data \(B\) number of times
  • Follow steps 2 and 3 of nonparametric bootstrapping

Multivariate Normal Distribution

\[\begin{equation} \mathbf{\Sigma} \left( \hat{\theta} \right) = \begin{bmatrix} \hat{\sigma}^{2}_{X} & \hat{\alpha} \hat{\sigma}_{X}^{2} & \hat{\alpha} \hat{\beta} \hat{\sigma}_{X}^{2} + \hat{\tau}^{\prime} \hat{\sigma}_{X}^{2} \\ \hat{\alpha} \hat{\sigma}_{X}^{2} & \hat{\alpha}^{2} \hat{\sigma}_{X}^{2} + \hat{\sigma}_{\hat{\varepsilon}_{M}}^{2} & \hat{\alpha}^{2} \hat{\beta} \hat{\sigma}_{X}^{2} + \hat{\alpha} \hat{\tau}^{\prime} \hat{\sigma}_{X}^{2} + \hat{\beta} \hat{\sigma}_{\hat{\varepsilon}_{M}}^{2} \\ \hat{\alpha} \hat{\beta} \hat{\sigma}_{X}^{2} + \hat{\tau}^{\prime} \hat{\sigma}_{X}^{2} & \hat{\alpha}^{2} \hat{\beta} \hat{\sigma}_{X}^{2} + \hat{\alpha} \hat{\tau}^{\prime} \hat{\sigma}_{X}^{2} + \hat{\beta} \hat{\sigma}_{\hat{\varepsilon}_{M}}^{2} & \hat{\beta}^{2} \hat{\alpha}^{2} \hat{\sigma}_{X}^{2} + \hat{\beta}^{2} \hat{\sigma}_{\hat{\varepsilon}_{M}}^{2} + 2 \hat{\alpha} \hat{\beta} \hat{\tau}^{\prime} \hat{\sigma}_{X}^{2} + \hat{\tau}^{\prime} \hat{\sigma}_{X}^{2} + \hat{\sigma}_{\hat{\varepsilon}_{Y}}^{2} \end{bmatrix} \end{equation}\]

\[\begin{equation} \mathbf{\mu} \left( \hat{\theta} \right) = \begin{bmatrix} \bar{X} \\ \bar{M} = \hat{\delta}_M + \hat{\alpha} \bar{X} \\ \bar{Y} = \hat{\delta}_Y + \hat{\tau}^{\prime} \bar{X} + \hat{\beta} \hat{\delta}_M + \hat{\alpha} \hat{\beta} \bar{X} \end{bmatrix} \end{equation}\]

\[\begin{equation} X, M, Y \sim \mathrm{MVN} \left[ \mathbf{\mu} \left( \hat{\theta} \right), \mathbf{\Sigma} \left( \hat{\theta} \right) \right] \end{equation}\]

Nonnormal Predictor

\[\begin{equation} X \sim \mathrm{Exponential} \left( \lambda \right) \end{equation}\]

\[\begin{equation} M = \hat{\delta}_M + \hat{\alpha} X + \hat{\varepsilon}_M, \\ \hat{\varepsilon}_M \sim \mathcal{N} \left(\mu = 0, \hat{\sigma}^2_{\hat{\varepsilon}_M} \right) \end{equation}\]

\[\begin{equation} Y = \hat{\delta}_Y + \hat{\tau}^{\prime} X + \hat{\beta} M + \hat{\varepsilon}_Y, \\ \hat{\varepsilon}_Y \sim \mathcal{N} \left(\mu = 0, \hat{\sigma}^2_{\hat{\varepsilon}_Y} \right) \end{equation}\]

Parametric Assumption

  • Distributional assumptions are required since we are essentially simulating data using parameter estimates
  • Distributional assumptions are not uncommon in statistical methods

Simulation

Sample Sizes

\(20, 50, 75, 100, 150, 200, 250, 500, 1000\)

Effect Sizes

\(0.00, 0.10, 0.20, 0.30, 0.40, 0.50, 0.60, 0.70, 0.80, 0.90\)

Estimation

  • Ordinary Least Squares

\[\begin{equation} \boldsymbol{\hat{\beta}} = \left( \mathbf{X}^{\prime} \mathbf{X} \right)^{-1} \left( \mathbf{X}^{\prime} \mathbf{y} \right). \end{equation}\]

\[\begin{equation} \hat{\sigma}^2 = \frac{1}{n - k} \left( \mathbf{y} - \mathbf{X} \boldsymbol{\hat{\beta}} \right)^{\prime} \left( \mathbf{y} - \mathbf{X} \boldsymbol{\hat{\beta}} \right) \\ \end{equation}\]

Assessment

  • Miss rate, that is, the proportion of simulation cases where the confidence interval did not contain the population indirect effect.
